title: Latest News from Science Magazine
description: Keyword search result for Alerts: News Weekly Headlines -- New results matching your keyword search query (updated daily).

items.title: Trove of Mexican genomes could help guide prescribing decisions
items.description: Study reveals role of “fine-grained” ancestry in predicting response to painkillers, statins, and other drugs

items.title: Spacecraft captures a solar flare as it builds into an explosive outburst
items.description: Europe’s Solar Orbiter is helping researchers understand what causes the Sun to blast out radiation and particles

items.title: NASA ends support for planetary science advisory groups
items.description: Culling limits agency’s ability to tap independent advice

items.title: Which of Trump’s upheavals to U.S. science are likely to stick?
items.description: A future president could reverse many changes, but greater White House control of science agencies may be here to stay

items.title: NASA is making last-ditch attempt to contact tumbling Mars orbiter
items.description: After 12 years studying the Red Planet’s atmosphere, MAVEN has gone perilously quiet

items.title: Final funding bill for NIH pushes back against Trump cuts
items.description: Measure gives agency slight boost and blocks multiyear awards and cuts to indirect costs

items.title: As Greenland loses ice, global sea levels will rise—and its own will fall
items.description: The island is rebounding from ice melt so fast that scientists are rethinking how Earth’s interior works

items.title: No bull: This Austrian cow has learned to use tools
items.description: First evidence for tool use in cattle includes a skill previously seen only in humans and chimpanzees

items.title: Nearly one-third of social media research has undisclosed ties to industry, preprint claims
items.description: Industry-linked studies were also more likely to focus on particular topics, suggesting these ties may be skewing the field

items.title: Purdue blocks admission of many Chinese grad students in unwritten policy
items.description: Faculty members say university is overreacting to pressure from the Trump administration and Congress
